Graphical abstract The recent development of heterogeneous catalysts for the synthesis of valuable organic carbonates from CO2 through various synthetic routes has been reviewed. The supported ionic liquids are worthy of further research. The mechanisms of acid–base or electrophile–nucleophile catalysis proposed in the literature will be valuable for the design and fabrication of high-performance catalysts. In this review article, we report the recent developments of heterogeneous catalysts for the synthesis of cyclic and dimethyl carbonates from CO2 through various routes. The synthesis of cyclic carbonates via cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides is one of the few processes that have been commercialized. Compared to the many effective homogeneous catalysts, the heterogeneous catalysts have the advantages of being superior in stability and reusability. However, of the reported catalysts including metal oxides, zeolites, smectite, supported organic bases, metal complexes, and ionic liquids, none can be considered as highly active and selective under mild conditions. Also, heterogeneous catalysts used in other routes do not perform satisfactorily. The supported ionic liquids have attracted much more attention and are worthy of further research for the cycloaddition reaction. We predict that the mechanisms of acid–base or electrophile–nucleophile catalysis proposed in the literature will be valuable for the design and fabrication of high-performance catalysts. Keywords Carbon dioxide utilization Cyclic carbonate Dimethyl carbonate Heterogeneous catalysts 1 Introduction Despite being blamed for global warming, CO2 is an economical C1 resource. It is abundant, nontoxic, and renewable. In recent decades, the transformation of CO2 to valuable chemicals has attracted much attention [1–4]. Researches have been conducted on CO2 hydrogenation, CO2 cycloaddition to epoxides, CO2 carbonylation of amines or alcohols, CO2 reduction under photoirradiation or electrolytic conditions, and the like. The methodologies involve: (i) using high-energy starting materials such as H2 to convert CO2 to unsaturated compounds and molecules of small-membered rings; (ii) choosing oxidized low-energy synthetic targets such as organic carbonates; (iii) shifting the equilibrium to the product side by removing particular compounds; (iv) supplying physical energy such as light or electricity [3]. However, due to the inert property of CO2, the use of CO2 as a feedstock in industrial processes is rare. Organic carbonates can be roughly categorized into cyclic and linear carbonates, such as ethylene carbonate (EC), propylene carbonate (PC) and dimethyl carbonate (DMC). In each molecule of cyclic carbonate and DMC, there are three oxygen atoms; from a thermodynamic point of view, these are suitable targets when CO2 is used as starting material [3]. With the rising demand of organic carbonates, the use of CO2 as a raw material to synthesize organic carbonates has been studied extensively. The synthesis of cyclic carbonates via cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides is one of the few catalytic processes that have been commercialized. Both homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts have advantages and shortcomings. Normally, homogeneous catalytic systems show higher catalytic activity than their heterogeneous counterparts. Nevertheless, heterogeneous catalysts can offer technical advantages related to stability, separation, handling, and reuse of catalysts as well as reactor design. In industrial processes, production cost can be reduced significantly if a heterogeneous catalyst of high efficiency is deployed. In this review article, we summarize the heterogeneous catalysts fabricated for the generation of valuable organic carbonates via reacting CO2 with organic compounds such as epoxides, glycol and methanol. Most of the cited works were published in the past 10 years. 2 Transformation of CO2 into cyclic carbonate Cyclic carbonates, e.g., EC and PC, are organic compounds that can be used as polar solvents, as electrolytes in lithium secondary batteries, as precursors for synthesizing polycarbonates and polyurethanes, and as raw materials in a wide range of chemical reactions [1–5]. Industrially, cyclic carbonates are synthesized by cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides. In addition, there are two potentially viable routes: (i) reaction of CO2 with glycol, and (ii) oxidative carboxylation of olefin with CO2. 2.1 Cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides One of the few commercial routes using CO2 as a raw material is the insertion of CO2 into epoxides to produce cyclic carbonates (Scheme 1 ). In terms of “green chemistry” and “atom economy”, the process is promising because CO2 can be incorporated into epoxides with no formation of side products [6]. In the past decades, numerous catalyst systems have been developed for this transformation. The high-efficiency ones are those involving the use of homogeneous catalysts such as organometallic complexes [7–21], phosphines [22–24], organic bases [25–27], and ionic liquids [1,28–38]. Nevertheless, in view of technical advantages, systems using heterogeneous catalysts have also been investigated. 2.1.1 Metal oxide catalysts Bhanage et al. used metal oxides such as MgO, CaO, ZrO2, ZnO, Al2O3, CeO2, and La2O3 that are relatively cheap and simple to prepare as catalysts for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates from CO2 and epoxides in the presence of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) (Table 1 , entries 1–9) [39]. Among the metal oxides, La2O3 exhibited the highest PC yield (54.1%) (Table 1, entry 4) whereas MgO showed the highest selectivity (92.0%) (Table 1, entry 8). Compared to the results of Bhanage et al. (Table 1, entries 8 and 9), higher PC and styrene carbonate (SC) yields were obtained by Yano et al. over MgO (Table 1, entries 10 and 11) [40]. The discrepancy in reactivity could be a result of differences in reaction conditions as well as in MgO and DMF concentrations. In the presence of DMF and CH2Cl2, Nb2O5 (Table 1, entries 12 and 13) showed even better activity [41]. It is apparent that the presence of DMF (a basic compound) is important for the cycloaddition reaction. Actually, by itself DMF can act as a catalyst for the synthesis of SC from styrene oxide (SO) and CO2 (Table 1, entry 18) [25]. It is likely that besides acting as a solvent, DMF functions as a co-catalyst in the cycloaddition reactions. From Table 1, one can see that the performance of the metal oxide catalysts is not satisfactory. Much higher catalytic activities were observed over mixed metal oxides or mixed metal–nonmetal oxides [42–44]. The Mg–Al mixed oxides prepared by calcination of the corresponding hydrotalcites are effective for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates from CO2 and various epoxides in the presence of DMF (Table 1, entries 14 and 15) [42]. Moreover, the NH3-TPD results indicated that acid sites co-exist with basic sites on the surfaces of the Mg–Al oxides (Mg/Al=5, calcined at 400°C) that are catalytically active, and there are no acid sites on the MgO and mixed oxides with Mg/Al ratio of 3 that are catalytically less active. Therefore, researchers deduced that the catalysis of the active Mg–Al mixed oxides could be caused by the cooperation of both acid and basic sites. The typical mechanism of acid–base catalysis over Mg–Al mixed oxide has been proposed by Yamaguchi et al. (Scheme 2 ) [42]. Other acid–base bifunctional systems such as ZnO–SiO2 xerogels with TBAB as co-catalyst (Table 1, entry 15) [43] and Cs–Si–P oxide with no co-catalyst or solvent (Table 1, entry 16) [44] showed high performance for the synthesis of PC from CO2 and propylene oxide (PO). The authors also consider that the bifunctional action of acid and basic sites is crucial. It has been reported that Zn-containing catalysts showed high efficiency for the cycloaddition reaction, and Zn2+ was regarded as essential for epoxide activation [45–47]. We prepared Mg-modified Zn–Al mixed oxides (Mg–Zn–Al oxide) by calcination of the corresponding hydrotalcites, and observed good catalytic activity and selectivity for cycaloaddition of CO2 to PO for PC generation under mild conditions. The characterization of the acid–base properties of the mixed oxides indicated that both acid and basic sites exist on the surface, and that sites of moderate basicity are beneficial to the reaction [48]. Although triethylamine is used, most of the triethylamine can be separated by the delivery method because of the poor solubility of triethylamine in PC. 2.1.2 Zeolite and smectite catalysts The basicity and reactivity of zeolites can be improved by incorporation of alkali metal oxide clusters into the pores of zeolites. To elucidate the role of occluded alkali species, Davis et al. [49–51] studied the performance of various alkali-modified X- and Y-zeolites for the cycloaddition of CO2 to ethylene oxide (EO). The results indicated that the occluded alkali metal oxides promote catalytic activity, and activity increases with the electropositivity of the alkali metal cations: Na+ <K+ <Cs+. Interestingly, the presence of a small amount of water enhances the rate of EC formation. Alkali- and alkaline-earth-modified Engelhard Titanosilicate-10 (ETS-10) molecular sieve catalysts also show activity for the synthesis of PC from CO2 and PO [52,53]. The alkali-modified catalysts are significantly more effective than the alkaline-earth-modified ones. In the case of ETS-10 catalyst, adsorption of a small amount of water greatly enhances the rate of cycloaddition reaction without significant formation of glycol side-products [53]; a similar phenomenon was observed in the cycloaddition reaction over modified zeolites [49,51]. Doskocil [53] considered that the roles of water adsorbed onto ETS-10 or alkali-modified ETS-10 catalyst are: (i) to enhance the Brönsted acidity of the ETS-10 surface, (ii) to produce localized carbonic acid sites that take part in the reaction, (iii) to enhance the transport of reactants to interior active sites, and (iv) to effectively modify the alkali metal oxide to produce sites of high turnover frequency (TOF). The processes indicate that the cycloaddition reaction follows an acid–base mechanism. Despite the improvement of catalytic activity of zeolites via modification with alkali metal oxides and addition of suitable amounts of water, the yield of cyclic carbonate is still low (<55%) [49–53]. When one uses organic bases or quaternary ammonium salts as co-catalyst and CH2Cl2 as solvent, titanosilicate molecular sieve (TS-1) showed good catalytic activity for the cycloaddition of CO2 to epichlorohydrin [54]. For example, when 4-(N,N-dimetylamino)-pyridine (DMAP) was used as co-catalyst, epichlorohydrin conversion and cyclic carbonate selectivity were 94.2 and 97.0%, respectively, at 160°C and 0.69MPa CO2 initial pressure in a reaction time of 4h. Over TS-1 or the co-catalyst individually, both epoxide conversion and cyclic carbonate selectivity were low. The results indicated that, when catalyst and co-catalyst are present, the rate of cycloaddition increases synergistically. The synergistic increase (defined as the ratio of TOF observed in the presence of both TS-1 and co-catalyst to the sum of TOFs when the reaction was conducted in the presence of TS-1 and co-catalyst separately) increases in the order: TS-1+Ph3P (1.16)<TS-1+DMAP (2.14)<TS-1+pyridine (2.43)<TS-1+Bu4PBr (2.73)<TS-1+Bu4NBr (2.86). (The numbers in brackets are the corresponding synergistic increases.) Smectite is a layered clay mineral, and its acidic and basic properties can be tuned by introducing transition and alkali metal ions into the sheet and/or interlayer structure. Fujita et al. [55] reported that the reaction of PO and CO2 to produce PC occurred over Mg-, Ni- and Mg–Ni-containing smectite that were modified with different amounts of Na+, K+, and Li+. The catalytic activity strongly depended on the elemental composition. With further addition of K+ into the Na-modified Mg-containing smectite, PO conversion and PC selectivity increased. The yield of PC tended to increase with the total amount of Na+ and K+ incorporated. The highest PC yield could reach 80.7% at 150°C and 8.0MPa CO2 pressure. However, catalytic activity became unsatisfactory when potassium was replaced by lithium or magnesium by nickel. Although the yield of PC is not high over this kind of catalyst, the absences of a co-catalyst and solvent are the main advantage in the view point of “green chemistry”. 2.1.3 Supported catalysts Compared to the catalysts of metal oxides and modified zeolites, homogeneous catalysts such as organic bases [25–27], organometallic complexes [7–21], and ionic liquids [1,28–38] usually show better activity and selectivity in cycloaddition reactions. However, the homogeneous systems have serious disadvantages in terms of product separation. For preparation of effective heterogeneous catalysts, catalysts that are used homogeneously are immobilized on suitable supports (e.g., mesoporous materials and biopolymers). Most of the results of this kind are listed in Table 2 . 2.1.3.1 Supported organic base catalysts Guanidine (7-methyl-1,5,7-triazabicyclo[4.4.0]dec-5-ene, MTBD) and its heterogeneous counterpart, obtained by covalently bonding 1,5,7-triazabicyclo[4.4.0]dec-5-ene (TBD) to MCM-41 molecular sieve (MCM-41-TBD), were investigated for the cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides in the presence of acetonitrile [26]. Over MCM-41-TBD, although SC yield and selectivity can reach 90 and 92%, respectively, at 140°C and 5.0MPa initial CO2 pressure, a much longer reaction time (70h) is required. Although the production of SC over supported catalyst MCM-41-TBD is lower than that in homogeneous reaction using MTBD, the use of MCM-41-TBD is still desirable because the catalyst can be easily recovered and reused. Ratnasamy et al. [56–58] investigated SBA-15 and Ti4+- or Al3+-functionalized SBA-15 that had been modified by nitrogen-based organic molecules of various basic strength (viz., alkyl amines (–NH2), adenine, imidazole, and guanine). They found that the adenine catalysts show better activity, plausibly due to the sites of intermediate basicity at which CO2 is not held either too weakly or too strongly. Moreover, the introduction of Lewis acidic Ti4+ and Al3+ ions to SBA-15 results in enhanced epoxide adsorption and hence improved catalytic activity. Furthermore, DMAP also can be immobilized onto SBA-15 for cycloaddition of CO2 to PO [59]. Besides mesoporous molecular sieves, silica (SiO2) was also used as support of organic base catalyst. Zhang et al. [60] observed catalytic activity towards the cycloaddition reaction over SiO2-supported amine catalysts (NH2/SiO2, NH(CH2)2NH2/SiO2 and TBD/SiO2). According to the results, catalytic activity is in the order of TBD/SiO2 >NH(CH2)2NH2/SiO2 >NH2/SiO2, consistent with the order of basic strength of the amines. Over TBD/SiO2 at 2.0MPa initial CO2 pressure, PC is obtained almost quantitatively at 150°C in 20h. When the surface of TBD/SiO2 was modified by methyl groups to remove the surface hydroxyls, the PO conversion sharply decreased from 99.5 to 0.2% under equal reaction conditions. This observation strongly suggests the importance of the silanol groups. A reaction mechanism has been proposed by Zhang et al. (Scheme 3 ) [60]. As reported by Jagtap et al., SiO2-supported polyvinyl pyridine also showed effective activity for the cycloaddition reaction [61]. 2.1.3.2 Supported organometallic complexes catalysts The uses of organometallic complexes of Cr, Co, Ni, Al, Mn, Zn, Ru, and Re, of various types (salen [7–15], porphyrin [16–18] or others [19–21]) as homogeneous catalysts have been reported to show good catalytic activity for the syntheses of cyclic carbonates through cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides in the presence of a basic co-catalyst. In terms of the high complexation ability of chelate complexes, immobilization of the complexes to a suitable support is an attractive strategy for fabrication of stable and reusable heterogeneous catalysts. Chromium salen complexes were anchored on aminopropyl-funcationalized SiO2, ITQ-2 and MCM-41 [62–64]. Baleizâo et al. [62] reported that the chiral Cr–salen complexes immobilized on SiO2, ITQ-2 and MCM-41 showed enantioselectivity for ring opening of cyclohexeneoxide with trimethylsilyl azide. The complexes anchored via coordination with Cr showed high cyclohexene oxide conversion (100%) and enantioselectivity (up to 70% enantiomeric excess (ee)), but there was severe leaching of the complex into solution. In the case of having the complex attached to the surface via covalent linkage to the ligand, leaching of the complex was not observed but epoxide conversion and ee value were low (below 70 and 20%, respectively). Results analogous to these observations were reported when the Cr–salen complexes immobilized on ITQ-2 and SiO2 were used as catalysts [63,64]. The complex anchored through coordination with Cr showed higher activity in the first run, but reusability was poor in comparison to that anchored via covalent linkage with the ligand. In contrast to the results of Baleizâo et al. [62], Alvaro et al. [63] and Ramin et al. [64], Jutz et al. [15] observed that, besides superiority in stability and reusability, the manganese salen complexes covalently immobilized showed better catalytic performance than that immobilized via coordination. The authors attributed the inferior performance of the latter to the formation of inactive surface species and/or the fact that Mn(III) is less suitable than Cr(III) to form stable six-coordinated complexes with an amino ligand. Nevertheless, the covalently immobilized catalyst lost its halide ligand during the catalytic reaction because the halide acted as a nucleophile in epoxide activation. Without addition of a halide such as Et4NBr, catalytic activity dropped drastically after the first run. Over aluminum phthalocyanine complex covalently bonded to MCM-41 and using n-Bu4NBr as co-catalyst, Lu et al. [65] observed good catalyst stability as well as catalytic activity in 10 cycles of cycloaddition reaction. Wong et al. [66] also reported that a tricarbonyl Re(I) complex anchored on a pyrrolidinium moiety (ionic liquid) could be reused over 10 cycles with only slight decreases in conversion (from 98 to 95%) in the presence of pyrrolidinium bromide as reaction medium. However, due to the homogeneous nature, recycling of the Re complex has to be done by means of extraction. Besides inorganic materials such as SiO2, SBA-15 and MCM-41, polymers were also used as supports to immobilize metal complexes [67]. Furthermore, Lu et al. demonstrated that immobilized metal complex (Co–salen) could be used in a flow reactor for continuous cycloaddition reactions [68]. Nevertheless, the application of the immobilized complexes is somehow limited due to drawbacks such as poor reusability of catalyst and the need of a solvent or co-catalyst. 2.1.3.3 Supported ionic liquid catalysts In recent years, ionic liquids have been extensively used as catalysts and/or alternative solvents in organic synthesis. Peng and Deng reported the first use of ionic liquids for the synthesis of cyclic carbonate [30]. Since then, numerous ionic liquids such as quaternary ammonium, phosphonium, imidazolium and pyridinium were used for cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides for the generation of cyclic carbonates [1,28–38]. For better separation and reuse of catalyst, the immobilization of ionic liquids on recyclable solid materials has been a topic of investigation. Xiao et al. [69] reported the first example of efficient addition of CO2 to epoxides to form cyclic carbonates over ionic liquid (3-n-butyl-1-propyl-imidazolium)-grafted SiO2, in which metal salts were used as co-catalysts. It was observed that the cations and anions of the co-catalysts have an influence on PC yield but not on PC selectivity (>98%). The activity decreases in the order of Zn2+ >Ni2+ >Co2+ >Fe3+ ≈Cu2+ ≈Al3+ >Cu+ (Cl− as common anion), and Br− ≈Cl− >OAc− >SO4 2− (Zn2+ as common cation). In the case of ZnCl2 as co-catalyst, 95% yield and >98% selectivity for the synthesis of PC from CO2 and PO were achieved at 110°C and 1.5MPa initial CO2 pressure in 1h. However, the yield of PC significantly decreased from 95 to 86% when the catalyst was reused for the second time; the loss of ionic liquid was considered to be the main reason. Wang et al. reported that SiO2-supported quaternary ammonium and imidazolium salts are efficient and recyclable catalysts for the cycloaddition reaction (PC yield>95%) [70,71]. The catalytic activity among unsupported quaternary ammonium salts strongly depends on the anions (order of activity: n-Bu4NBr> n-Bu4NI≈ n-Bu4NCl> n-Bu4NF), but such an influence becomes less apparent among the SiO2-supported counterparts [70]. It was noted that the length of the alkyl chain of supported quaternary ammonium bromides (Me4NBr, Et4NBr, n-Pr4NBr, and n-Bu4NBr) has little effect on the cycloaddition reaction; by itself Me4NBr is inactive for PC synthesis, while the others are highly active under identical reaction conditions [70]. Similar results were obtained over SiO2-supported 3-butyl-1-methyl-imidazolium salts of different anions (BF4 − >Br− >PF6 −) [71]. Such synergistic effect of support and catalyst was also observed by Zhao et al. over chitosan immobilized 2-hydroxypropyl trimethylammonium chloride [72], and by Takahashi et al. [73] and Sakai et al. [74] over SiO2-immobilized phosphonium halides. In view of the higher catalytic activity over the supported catalysts, it is apparent that SiO2 and chitosan have an important role to play in cyclic carbonate synthesis over catalysts of supported ionic liquids. Nevertheless, the mechanisms of such synergistic roles are unclear. Another method of anchoring ionic liquids on a solid material is by means of copolymerization of an ionic liquid with the monomer of a material. For example, 3-butyl-1-vinylimidazolium chloride was copolymerized with cross-linked divinylbenzene, and the ionic liquid was covalently anchored on the polymer matrix [75]. Furthermore, like the cases of immobilized organometallic complexes, molecular sieves were also used as effective materials to support ionic liquids [76,77]. We have prepared SBA-15 and Al-SBA-15 that are grafted with hydroxyl ionic liquid (3-(2-hydroxyl-ethyl)-1-propylimidazolium bromide, HEPrIMBr). The catalysts showed higher catalytic activity than other supported ionic liquid catalysts reported in the literature for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates from CO2 and epoxides under mild conditions. When PO was allowed to react with CO2 (initial pressure 2.0MPa) at 140°C for 1h, PC was obtained quantitatively with 98.6% yield over SBA-15-immobilized HEPrIMBr [78]. Other supported catalysts for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates through cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides are poly(4-vinylpyridine)-supported ZnX2 (X=Cl, Br, I) [79], ZrO2-supported SmOCl [80], resin-supported Au [81], insoluble ion exchange resins (one type of polystyrene-supported catalysts containing an ammonium salt or amino group) [6], chitosan-supported ZnCl2 (using 1-butyl-3-methylimidazole halides as co-catalysts) [82], and polyaniline- supported HX (X=I, Br, Cl) [83]. The catalysts show certain catalytic activity for the cycloaddition of epoxides to CO2. Although the supported heterogeneous catalysts show effective catalytic activity, the stability and reusability are not good enough for commercialization. 2.1.4 Other heterogeneous catalysts Zn-containing catalysts show good catalytic activity for the cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides. Sankar et al. [46] reported that, in conjunction with DMAP, Zn-substituted sandwich-type polyoxometalate Na12[WZn3(H2O)2(ZnW9O34)2]·46H2O showed good activity. In the presence of CH2Cl2 as solvent and at 0.4MPa initial CO2 pressure, almost quantitative conversion (97%) with selectivity>97% was achieved at 140°C in 3h. The zinc-based hydroxyapatite (ZnHAP) prepared by exchanging hydroxyapatite (Ca10(PO4)6(OH)2) with zinc nitrate also found to be efficient for the cycloaddition reaction in the presence of an organic base as co-catalyst [47]. When trans-1-deuterio-1,2-hexene oxide was used as substrate, selectivity to the corresponding trans-1-deuterio-1,2-hexene carbonate was 82% over ZnHAP. The results indicated that Zn as Lewis acid activates epoxide, while the organic base attacks the less sterically hindered carbon atom to open the epoxide ring. Then the generated oxy anionic species reacts with CO2 to give the corresponding cyclic carbonate (path A of Scheme 4 ). However, because of the minor formation of the cis-isomer, the participation of CO2 activated by Lewis base, i.e., [R3N+C(O)O−] in the ring opening step of epoxide cannot be ruled out (path B of Scheme 4) [47]. In most studies, it is regarded that epoxide and CO2 are, respectively, activated by acid and basic sites. It is also believed that acid–base bifunctional catalysts perform well in the synthesis of cyclic carbonates via cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides. Hence, heterogeneous catalysts that display high efficiency should have both acid and base properties. 2.2 Synthesis of cyclic carbonate from CO2 and glycol Five-membered cyclic carbonates are commercially important. They are used as aprotic polar solvents, precursor of polycarbonate, electrolytes in lithium batteries, and elsewhere. Another use of a cyclic carbonate such as PC and EC is for the formation of DMC. Industrially DMC can be synthesized from methanol and PC [3,84,85], and propylene glycol (PG) is a by-product in the transesterification process (Scheme 5 ). To avoid wastage of PG and for better utilization of CO2, it is desirable to develop a catalytic process for the direct synthesis of cyclic carbonate from glycol and CO2 (Scheme 6 ). Tomishige et al. [86,87] reported for the first time the syntheses of EC and PC via the interaction of CO2 with ethylene glycol (EG) and PG, respectively, over CeO2–ZrO2 solid solution in the presence of acetonitrile. They found that ZrO2 by itself exhibits almost no activity, and that the temperature for the calcination of CeO2–ZrO2 catalysts with different Ce contents (expressed as Ce/(Ce+Zr)) has a significant effect on catalytic activity. In terms of PC yield, the CeO2–ZrO2 catalyst with Ce/(Ce+Zr)=0.33 calcined at 1000°C shows the best performance. However, the formation of cyclic carbonate and H2O from glycol and CO2 is a reversible process and cyclic carbonate yield is limited by equilibrium. Although EC and PC selectivity can be as high as 100%, the maximum conversion of EG and PG is low, only about 2.0 and 1.3%, respectively. Alkali metal carbonates have been used as effective homogeneous catalysts for the syntheses of PC from PG and CO2 in the presence of acetonitrile; catalytic activity is in the order of Cs2CO3 >K2CO3 >Na2CO3, consistent with basicity order [85]. Chen et al. [88] investigated the use of various inorganic materials, viz., γ-Al2O3, SiO2, activated carbon, MgO, supported K2CO3, as heterogeneous catalysts. Under optimized reaction conditions, PC yield and selectivity was 9.6 and 74.4%, respectively, over activated carbon supported-K2CO3. A series of zinc oxide catalysts using alkali salts as modifiers were prepared by Huang et al. and their catalytic activities were evaluated in the presence of acetonitrile [89]. Among the catalysts, the KI-modified one showed the best catalytic efficiency (26.0% PC yield and 61.0% PC selectivity). The authors suggested that acetonitrile acted not only as solvent but also as an agent for the removal of water (Eq. 1 of Scheme 7 ) [85,89]; a similar view is held by Chen et al. [88]. Interestingly, when ammonium carbonate ((NH4)2CO3) was added, there was significant improvement of PC selectivity. It was observed that, with more (NH4)2CO3 added, the yield of by-product propylene glycol-2-acetate decreased and gradually reached zero. It is well known that (NH4)2CO3 decomposes readily to NH3, H2O and CO2. It is likely that the reaction steps of Eqs. (1)–(3) in Scheme 7 take place, and that the NH3 produced in (NH4)2CO3 decomposition inhibits acetamide from being hydrolyzed to acetic acid; this allows the improvement of PC selectivity [85,89]. The use of acetonitrile in chemical reactions cannot be considered as “green”. Using magnesium and magnesium oxide of low-toxicity as catalysts, Du et al. [90] reported PC was produced in high selectivity via PG carbonylation with CO2 without any involvement of organic solvents or additives. They demonstrated that the catalysts could be applied to a variety of 1,2-diols, such as glycol and phenyl glycol, forming the corresponding cyclic carbonate in 100% selectivity, but 1,2-diol conversion was far from being satisfactory. The reaction carried out over Mg or MgO may involve three steps (Scheme 8 ) [90]. First, Mg or MgO reacts with PG to give Mg alkoxide. Since the metal–oxygen bond is susceptible to CO2 insertion, cyclic Mg carbonate is formed through the insertion of CO2 to Mg alkoxide. Subsequently, intramolecular nucleophilic attacks of alkoxy groups on carbonyl carbon atoms result in the release of PC and regeneration of catalyst. Homogeneous catalysts such as organic Sn-compounds (Bu2SnO and Bu2Sn(OMe)2) [91], organic bases (TBD) [92], and metal acetate (Zn, Pb, Cu, Co, Mg, K, and Ni) [93] have been proved to be active for PC synthesis from CO2 and PG. However, they are not industrially applicable. Due to equilibrium limitation, the catalytic activities over the catalysts are low and the PC yields are even poorer than those observed over certain heterogeneous catalysts. 2.3 Oxidative carboxylation of olefin with CO2 The idea of synthesizing cyclic carbonates from olefins and CO2 directly is appealing. The method involves two processes, viz., epoxidation of olefins to give epoxides and cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides to give cyclic carbonates. According to this method, CO2 is used as a building block, and epoxide isolation is not necessary. There are a number of reports on the direct synthesis of carbonates from olefins using homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts [54,94–97]. Sun et al. [94,95] found that direct oxidative carboxylation of styrene to styrene carbonate (SC) is feasible in the presence of ionic liquids. The reaction was conducted by using tert-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP) as oxidant in the presence of quaternary ammonium halides or imidazolium salts as catalysts. Under optimized reaction conditions, the yield of SC reached 38% in the presence of TBAB [95]. Sun et al. also reported a catalyst system that consists of Au/SiO2, ZnBr2, and TBAB for one-pot synthesis of SC from styrene, organic peroxide, and CO2 [96]. Au/SiO2 is active for the epoxidation of styrene while ZnBr2 and TBAB cooperatively catalyze the subsequent cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxide. Using cumene hydroperoxide as oxidant, the highest carbonate yield of 45% is obtained under mild reaction conditions (80°C, 1MPa CO2). Few heterogeneous catalysts have been studied for use in the oxidative carboxylation of olefins with the purpose of generating cyclic carbonates. Aresta et al. reported that Nb2O5 showed effective activity for the cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxide [41] as well as for the oxidative carboxylation of styrene with CO2 [97]. However, because of byproducts such as benzaldehyde and benzoic acid, SC selectivity was low (1–2%). Nevertheless, when NbCl5 was added as co-catalyst, carbonate yield was 11%. Srivastava et al. [54] used TS-1 and Ti-modified MCM-41 (TiMCM-41) as catalysts for the synthesis of cyclic carbonate from olefins in a single reactor. Initially, they carried out the epoxidation of olefin using H2O2 or TBHP as oxidant. With the introduction of CO2 and the use of co-catalyst DMAP (an organic base) in the presence of CH2Cl2, the resulting mixture was subject to CO2 cycloaddition. An olefin conversion of 54.6% and cyclic carbonate selectivity of 55.6% were obtained over TS-1 when allylchloride was the olefin and H2O2 the oxidant. When the olefin is styrene, conversion was 50.4% and SC selectivity was 26%. Using TiMCM-41 as catalyst and TBHP as oxidant, the conversion of olefins to epoxides were low (allylchloride conversion=13.3% and styrene conversion=44%), but further conversion of epoxide to cyclic carbonate was almost 100%. Even though the cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxide can be conducted effectively and selectively, the poor selectivity and the need of using expensive oxidant in the epoxidation step hinder the oxidative carboxylation process from being industrialized. In other words, it is crucial to use an oxidant that is economical and a catalyst that is highly efficient and selective. 3 Transformation of CO2 to DMC As an environmentally benign compound with versatile chemical reactivity, DMC has been studied intensively. DMC can be used as solvent, fuel additive, precursor for resins, and as starting material for organic synthesis via carbonylation and methylation, replacing toxic phosgene and dimethyl sulfate [98]. Several routes are known for DMC production, e.g., phosgene–methanol process, transesterification of cyclic carbonate with methanol, carbon monoxide–methyl nitrite process, and one-step gas-phase oxidative carbonylation of methanol [99,100]. At present, DMC is synthesized mainly via the oxidative carbonylation of methanol with O2 and CO. The process is hazardous because the reactant mixture is highly flammable and chemicals such as methanol and CO are toxic. In this section, three synthesis routes using CO2 are addressed. They are: (i) direct synthesis of DMC from CO2 and methanol; (ii) one-pot synthesis of DMC from CO2, methanol and epoxides; (iii) synthesis of DMC from acetals (or ortho-esters) and CO2. 3.1 Direct synthesis of DMC from CO2 and methanol In terms of material cost and synthetic strategy, the direct synthesis of DMC from methanol and CO2 (Scheme 9 ) is attractive. Tomishige et al. [101] reported that ZrO2 could be used as a selective catalyst for the reaction. However, because of equilibrium limitation, despite almost 100% DMC selectivity, methanol conversion was extremely low (0.34% in 2h) under the reaction conditions of 160°C and initial CO2 pressure of 5.0MPa. Over SiO2, Al2O3, TiO2, H-ZSM5, H-mordenite, ZnO, MoO3, and Bi2O3, Tomishige et al. observed no formation of DMC. According to the TPD results of CO2 and NH3 co-adsorption, the neighboring acid and basic sites on ZrO2 are regarded as the active sites for DMC formation [101,102]. A reaction mechanism was proposed based on DRIFT results of adsorbed CO2 and methanol (Scheme 10 ) [102]. Detailed in situ Raman and infrared spectroscopic studies of DMC synthesis from CO2 and methanol over ZrO2 were carried out by Xie and Bell [103], and Jung and Bell [104]. The results indicated that the reaction occurs in three steps: (i) the adsorption of methanol, (ii) the addition of CO2 to surface methoxide groups to form monomethyl carbonate groups, and (iii) the reaction of methanol with monomethyl carbonate groups to form DMC. A reaction mechanism of this kind (rather similar to that reported by Tomishige et al. [102]) is shown in Scheme 11 [104]. Moreover, the study also confirmed that the effectiveness of ZrO2 as a catalyst for the synthesis of DMC from CO2 and methanol is due to the presence of both Brönsted basic hydroxyl group (Zr–OH) and coordinately unsaturated Zr4+O2−; the Lewis acid–base pairs serve as active centers [104,105]. The addition of phosphoric acid (H3PO4) to ZrO2 catalysts promoted the activity of DMC synthesis, especially at low temperature [106]. The H3PO4 loading and the calcination temperature of catalysts have an effect on catalytic activity. Among the reported catalysts, the H3PO4/ZrO2 (P/Zr=0.05) calcined at 400°C shows the best performance, giving 0.63% DMC yield at 130°C and 5.0MPa initial CO2 pressure in 2h. The acid–base bifunctional property of H3PO4/ZrO2 (P/Zr=0.05) is responsible for its better activity in comparison to those of some other catalysts [107]. Jiang et al. reported that ZrO2 loaded with 12-tungstophosphoric acid (H3PW12O40/ZrO2) via a sol–gel method exhibited better activity than ZrO2 [108]. Under equal reaction conditions, DMC yield over H3PW12O40/ZrO2 (H3PW12O40 content=23.2%) was 9 times that over ZrO2. Moreover, the authors proposed a reaction mechanism similar to that of Jung and Bell [104] and Ikeda et al. [107]. As reported by Tomishige et al., binary CeO2–ZrO2 (Ce/(Ce+Zr)=0.2 and 0.33, calcined at 1000°C) catalysts also showed better catalytic activity than ZrO2 [109]. Although the activity can be improved by modification of ZrO2 with H3PO4, polyoxometalate, and cerium, the conversion of methanol is low due to reaction equilibrium. In some cases of DMC synthesis using homogeneous catalysts, dehydrated derivatives (e.g., ortho-esters and acetals) were used as starting material to minimize the effect of water presence [110–113]. Furthermore, the dehydrated derivatives (e.g., 2,2-dimethoxy propane, DMP) can act as a dehydrating agent to remove H2O (Scheme 12 ) [114]. When DMP is added to the reaction system, the conversion of methanol over CeO2–ZrO2 catalysts significantly increases. However, the effect of DMP addition is closely dependent on DMP concentration. At low DMP concentration, DMC formation is promoted, whereas at high DMP concentration, the rate of DMC formation decreases due to the decomposition of DMP to dimethyl ether and acetone. Besides binary CeO2–ZrO2 catalysts, CeO2 [115] and CeO x Ti1−x O2 [116] were used to synthesize DMC directly from CO2 and methanol. It was found that the catalytic performance of the catalysts is in the order of CeO0.1Ti0.9O2 >CeO x Ti1−x O2 (x =0.2–0.8)>ZrO2 >CeO2 >TiO2. It was reported that the loading of H3PW12O40 on CeO x Ti1−x O2 would also result in higher activity. Based on the results of NH3- and CO2-TPD characterization, researchers suggested that the acid–base bifunctional property of the catalyst is beneficial to the reaction [117]. The above reported processes for the synthesis of DMC from CO2 and methanol were all conducted in a batch reactor. Wu et al. [118] reported the use of a fixed-bed micro-gaseous reactor for continuous synthesis of DMC from CO2 and methanol using Cu–Ni/VSO (VSO=V2O5–SiO2) as catalyst. Compared to conventional catalytic reaction, the reaction that involved the use of membrane showed higher catalytic performance. Li and Zhong [119] investigated the application of supported membrane reactors for the synthesis of DMC from CO2 and methanol over Cu–KF/MgSiO; the results indicated that DMC yield and selectivity were enhanced as a result. Other catalysts such as H3PO4-modified V2O5 [120], organotin-grafted SBA-15 [121], and n-Bu2Sn(OMe)2 supported on polystyrene or silesquioxanes [122] showed some catalytic activity. Moreover, a novel photo-assistant synthetic process was reported by Wang et al. using copper-modified (Ni, V, and O) semiconductor complexes as catalysts [123]. Although numerous heterogeneous catalysts have been developed, the process is far from commercialization, mainly because of thermodynamic equilibrium limitations and the lack of proper dehydrating techniques. 3.2 One-pot synthesis of DMC from CO2, methanol and epoxide A main route for DMC generation is the transesterification of cyclic carbonates (such as, EC and PC; Scheme 5) that are synthesized via cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides (Scheme 1) with methanol. However, the two-step synthesis of DMC suffers disadvantages of high-energy consumption as well as high investment and production costs due to the requirement of the separation of intermediate, i.e., cyclic carbonates. There is hence the need to develop a technology for the one-pot synthesis of DMC from CO2, methanol and epoxides (Scheme 13 ). According to Bhanage et al. [39], MgO showed good selectivity in two-step synthesis of DMC. However, even though epoxide conversion is above 96% in one-pot synthesis of DMC from CO2, methanol and epoxides over the MgO catalyst, DMC selectivity is low (<30%) due to alcoholysis of epoxide. Modified smectite showed catalytic activity not only in the cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxide [55] but also in one-pot synthesis of DMC [124,125]. Mg-containing smectite was found to be catalytically effective (DMC yield=32.3%), and compared to MgO, the catalyst showed improved selectivity to DMC [124]. Fujita et al. examined the effects of quantity and kind of incorporated alkali atoms on the catalytic properties of a series of Mg-containing smectites incorporated with alkali hydroxide (NaOH, KOH, or LiOH) [125]. According to reactivity and CO2-TPD results, DMC yield increases while the extent of PO methanolysis decreases with rise in concentration of alkali atoms. It was also found that the total amount of basic sites of moderate and strong basicity is essential for the one-pot reaction. Nonetheless, the DMC yield is not high, due to reaction equilibrium as well as side methanolysis reactions. As homogeneous catalysts, alkali metal salts or a mixture of alkali metal salts show excellent catalytic performance in the one-pot synthesis of DMC [126,127]. For example, using a mixture of KI and K2CO3 (weight ratio of KI:K2CO3 =1:1) for synthesis of DMC from CO2, methanol and EO, one finds that DMC selectivity is above 73.0% at 100% EO conversion with less than 4.0% selectivity to by-product [126]. Heterogeneous catalysts with the active components highly dispersed onto an inorganic material were fabricated for the one-pot reaction. Chang et al. [128] reported that for synthesis of DMC from CO2, methanol and EO, calcined KI/ZnO and K2CO3–KI/ZnO catalysts are active and selective, giving DMC yields that exceeded 57% and less than 0.2% by-product. The authors also reported that the K2CO3–KI/ZnO catalyst could be reused 4 times without any obvious decrease in activity. When CaO, MgO and ZnO were used as supports, the order of activity and DMC selectivity was KI/ZnO>KI/MgO>KI/CaO, whereas the strength of basic sites followed the order of CaO>MgO>ZnO. Furthermore, the KI/ZnO doped with K2CO3 showed higher activity than that doped with KOH or NaOH. The authors hence deduced that sites of moderate base character were advantageous for the reaction. Catalysts of supported alkali salts such as MgO-supported K2CO3 and KCl [127], and 4A molecular sieve-supported KOH [129] were also found to be effective for the one-pot synthesis of DMC from CO2, methanol and PO. On the other hand, catalysts of supported ionic liquids could also be used for the one-pot synthesis of DMC. For example, choline hydroxide supported on MgO showed effective catalytic activity (DMC yield=65.4%), but reusability of catalyst was poor because there was significant decline in activity and DMC selectivity after the first run [130]. It is apparent that the key for one-pot synthesis of DMC is to develop catalysts that are effective for both the cycloaddition and transesterification reactions. 3.3 Synthesis of DMC from CO2 and acetal or ortho-ester Due to reasons such as catalyst deactivation, thermodynamic equilibrium limitation, and DMC hydrolysis caused by co-produced water, organometallic compounds such as tin methoxides are poor catalysts for the direct synthesis of DMC from CO2 and methanol [131]. Using dehydrated derivatives (e.g., ortho-esters and acetals) as starting materials, one can avoid the ill effect of water [110–113]. However, reports on the use of heterogeneous catalysts for such reactions are few. Chu et al. reported that polymer-supported quaternary ammonium iodide (an iodide exchanged anion-exchange resin) catalysts were effective for the synthesis of DMC from CO2 and trimethyl orthoesters [132]. However, the high cost of trimethyl orthoesters and the need of adding P2O5 for high DMC yield (46%) are the main disadvantages of such an approach. 4 Conclusion The recent developments of heterogeneous catalysts for CO2 utilization in the generation of useful organic carbonates such as cyclic carbonate and DMC have been described. Compared to the many effective homogeneous catalysts, the heterogeneous catalysts have the advantages of being superior in stability and reusability. However, most of heterogeneous catalysts have shortcoming(s) such as: (i) catalytic activity is unsatisfactory; (ii) solvents and/or co-catalysts are needed to improve activity and/or selectivity; (iii) relatively rigorous reaction conditions are required; (iv) reusability and stability are poor, especially for the supported-type catalysts. As for routes for the synthesis of cyclic carbonate and DMC by reacting CO2 with glycol and methanol, respectively, catalytic activities are limited by reaction equilibrium. Hence the design of new reaction processes and/or the use of new dehydrating agent are the key to achieve high yield and selectivity. coredata.dc:description: In this review article, we report the recent developments of heterogeneous catalysts for the synthesis of cyclic and dimethyl carbonates from CO2 through various routes. The synthesis of cyclic carbonates via cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides is one of the few processes that have been commercialized. Compared to the many effective homogeneous catalysts, the heterogeneous catalysts have the advantages of being superior in stability and reusability. However, of the reported catalysts including metal oxides, zeolites, smectite, supported organic bases, metal complexes, and ionic liquids, none can be considered as highly active and selective under mild conditions. Also, heterogeneous catalysts used in other routes do not perform satisfactorily. The supported ionic liquids have attracted much more attention and are worthy of further research for the cycloaddition reaction. We predict that the mechanisms of acid–base or electrophile–nucleophile catalysis proposed in the literature will be valuable for the design and fabrication of high-performance catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: The direct transformation of carbon dioxide to organic carbonates over heterogeneous catalysts
